importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The vote on delaying the Net Zero Framework occurred on this date, following President Trump's public threat and a shift in the IMO meeting's outcome.
The Net Zero Framework was initially approved by the IMO in April 2025, setting a precedent for global shipping emissions regulation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework was postponed until late 2025, creating uncertainty in maritime emissions regulation and investment planning.

keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) delayed formal approval of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by 12 months due to pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump.
The U.S. threatened sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on countries supporting the emissions regulation, influencing the vote in London.
The Net Zero Framework would have implemented a global carbon tax on shipping emissions, charging $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emitted.
The framework aims to reduce shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050.
Key supporters of the plan included China, the European Union, Brazil, Britain, and several other IMO members; opposition came from Russia and Saudi Arabia.
Argentina and Singapore, previously supportive, changed their stance to delay the framework's adoption.
The decision undermines global climate action and delays progress toward decarbonizing the maritime sector.
The International Chamber of Shipping expressed concern over lack of clarity for industry investment in decarbonization technologies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed the formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by 12 months after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened sanctions on countries supporting the plan. The NZF, which would have introduced a global carbon tax of $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emissions, was initially approved in April 2025. Trump's public backlash and threats of economic penalties influenced delegates in London to vote in favor of a delay, despite support from major nations like China, the EU, and Brazil. Countries such as Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed the framework, while Argentina and Singapore reversed their previous support. The decision undermines global climate action and creates uncertainty for the shipping industry, which urgently needs investment and policy clarity to decarbonize. Experts and climate advocates, including Vanuatu’s minister and UN Secretary-General Guterres, condemned the delay as a setback to climate goals and maritime sustainability.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
